values.description: Sometime the plugin is not loaded when running integrated\_main. Whether it's loaded or not seems to be random. The reason is World::Step\(\) only call LoadPlugins\(\) if SensorsInitialized\(\). However, dataPtr->sensorsInitialized variable is not initialized and its value can be true or false. gzserver calls sensors::run\_once\(\) to initialize sensors \(through Server::Run\(\)\), so it does not have this issue. To fix this problem, we first initialize sensorsInitialized correctly and add sensors::run\_once\(\) to integrated\_main.cc
values.title: Fix animited_box/integrated_main

values.description:
There were several bugs which causes animation to not load.

1. Frame values may be separated with tab instead of space. `boost::is_any_of("   ")` looks like a bug, it should probably be `boost::is_any_of(" \t")`
2. There is a infinite loop in `ColladaLoader::LoadAnimations`
3. Name of the skeleton imported from COLLOADA is based on its xml attribute `name` however, the animation is loaded based on the attribute `id`, if the node's `name` and `id` is different, animations may not load correctly.
values.title: fix issue #2582

summary.html:
There were several bugs which causes animation to not load.

  1. Frame values may be separated with tab instead of space. boost::is_any_of("   ") looks like a bug, it should probably be boost::is_any_of(" \t")
  2. There is a infinite loop in ColladaLoader::LoadAnimations
  3. Name of the skeleton imported from COLLOADA is based on its xml attribute name however, the animation is loaded based on the attribute id, if the node's name and id is different, animations may not load correctly.

values.description:
gazebo10 code freeze is imminent, and there are two pull requests that change ABI that are close but not quite ready (pull request #3038 and pull request #2957); so I've moved the ABI changes into this pull request that can be part of `10.0.0`, while the sonar geometry and actor pull requests can be in a subsequent patch or minor release

* add geometry field to sonar.proto before gazebo10 code freeze

* Add private dataPtr to Actor class so new private variables can be added without breaking ABI

values.description: This is a change to enable dynamic linking for Windows build \(correcting out-of-dated dllimport/dllexport usage\) for the downstream project using the same way to consume gazebo libraries. For example, like ROS on Windows, gazebo\_ros\_pkgs can consume the Gazebo library by using Gazebo-config.cmake like Linux environment.

values.description:
Fixing paths related issues observed in Windows build: \(It is not a exhaustive list but the problems observed initially blocking Gazebo working for ROS on Windows.\)

* Forward slash path \(or mixing forward\\backward slash\) usage on OGRE is not properly translated to the actual path, so normalize them before passed to OGRE.
* Fix exception observed when passing a position out of range in SystemPaths::UpdateModelPaths, SystemPaths::UpdateGazeboPaths, and SystemPaths::UpdatePluginPaths.
* Fix the logic to automatically trim “lib” \(which should check the prefix “lib” matched before trimming it\) in Windows build in plugin.hh.
values.title: [Gazebo9] Fixing paths related issues on Windows build.

* Fix the logic to automatically trim “lib” \(which should check the prefix “lib” matched before trimming it\) in Windows build in plugin.hh.

values.description:
‌

* this fixes the collada loader so models from mixamo.com can be loaded correctly. It should also fix issue #2582.

    List of changes:



    * `boost::split(words, line, boost::is_any_of(" "))` in `BVHLoader.cc` and `ColladaLoader.cc` looks like a bug as a result of tab being replaced with spaces, replaced with `boost::split(words, line, boost::is_any_of(" \t"));`
    * Scale the skeleton according to the collada's meter parameter
    * Import the whole scene in a Collada file as an actor, because animations may target the scene outside the skeleton, this is required so some animations work correctly
    * Allow `Skeleton` to store data of raw node weights with multiple vertices group. The raw node weights are overwritten when loading a new submesh, while not strictly required becauses submeshes are load sequentially, it is probably more "correct" to have the full node weights available.
    * Map the animation to the target bone's name as opposed to the id \(target bone is still chosen by the id\). Since the skeleton nodes are identified by its name in the rendering process, mapping the animations to id may result in missing animations.
    * Fix loading `<transparency>` tag, gazebo uses 0 opaque, collada uses 1 opaque. Note that is is separate from the `<transparent>` tag where the color is defined in the `opaque` attribute.
    * Separate the positions and normals from the texture mapping buffers. When doing software skinning OGRE requires the positions and normal to be in their own buffers, see `https://ogrecave.github.io/ogre/api/1.11/_animation.html` under `Vertex buffer arrangements`.
    
* remove unused includes
values.title: Gazebo9 collada mixamo fix

values.description:
* Fixes export visibility for plugins in environments that otherwise build static libs \(e.g. Windows\).

    * While gazebo libs are shared on Linux but static on Windows, plugin libs are always built shared. The plugin headers were mistakenly using `GAZEBO_VISIBLE`, which is defined based on the library type and intended for gazebo libs, instead of `GZ_PLUGIN_VISIBLE`, which is intended for plugin libs that are always shared.
values.title: Gazebo10 fix Windows plugin visibility

summary.raw:
* Fixes export visibility for plugins in environments that otherwise build static libs \(e.g. Windows\).

    * While gazebo libs are shared on Linux but static on Windows, plugin libs are always built shared. The plugin headers were mistakenly using `GAZEBO_VISIBLE`, which is defined based on the library type and intended for gazebo libs, instead of `GZ_PLUGIN_VISIBLE`, which is intended for plugin libs that are always shared.
summary.html:
• Fixes export visibility for plugins in environments that otherwise build static libs (e.g. Windows).

    • While gazebo libs are shared on Linux but static on Windows, plugin libs are always built shared. The plugin headers were mistakenly using GAZEBO_VISIBLE, which is defined based on the library type and intended for gazebo libs, instead of GZ_PLUGIN_VISIBLE, which is intended for plugin libs that are always shared.

values.description:
This pull request adds the VariableGearboxPlugin, which uses piecewise cubic Hermite splines to support arbitrary smooth input-output relationships between the input and output angles of a gearbox. This includes the plugin, an example world, a test, and some added API's to ODE to support this feature.

The ODE gearbox joint currently supports joint constraints of the form `angle1 = -ratio * angle2`. In order to support arbitrary constraint profiles, reference angles are added to the linear constraint: `angle1 - refAngle1 = -ratio * (angle2 - refAngle2)`. Then at each time step, the smooth input-output curve is linearized at the current joint state to compute refAngle1, refAngle2, and ratio and solved. API's for setting the refAngle's are added to ODE, which can be accessed via `SetParam` / `GetParam` in the physics Joint interface. Tests are added for these new API's to the `joint_spawn` test.

The `VariableGearboxPlugin` is a `ModelPlugin` that takes a `gearbox_joint_name` parameter and multiple `x_y_dydx` parameters. The `x_y_dydx` parameters specify points and slopes on the input-output curve. The snippet below is copied from `variable_gearbox_plugin.world`. Documentation of the spline math is provided in the code.

* x: angle of input joint
* y: angle of output joint
* dy/dx: instantaneous gear ratio of change in output / change in input.

~~~
<plugin name="variable_gearbox" filename="libVariableGearboxPlugin.so">
  <gearbox_joint_name>demo_joint_types::gearbox_demo</gearbox_joint_name>
  <x_y_dydx>1.2  -1.2  -1.0</x_y_dydx>
  <x_y_dydx>1.8  -7.5 -20.0</x_y_dydx>
</plugin>
~~~

The example world uses the `demo_joint_types` model, which has a pendulum connected via a gearbox to a flywheel. This plugin shifts the gear ratio from a low speed of the flywheel to a high speed as the pendulum swings.
values.title: VariableGearboxPlugin: use splines to support arbitrary smooth input-output gearbox profiles

summary.raw:
This pull request adds the VariableGearboxPlugin, which uses piecewise cubic Hermite splines to support arbitrary smooth input-output relationships between the input and output angles of a gearbox. This includes the plugin, an example world, a test, and some added API's to ODE to support this feature.

The ODE gearbox joint currently supports joint constraints of the form `angle1 = -ratio * angle2`. In order to support arbitrary constraint profiles, reference angles are added to the linear constraint: `angle1 - refAngle1 = -ratio * (angle2 - refAngle2)`. Then at each time step, the smooth input-output curve is linearized at the current joint state to compute refAngle1, refAngle2, and ratio and solved. API's for setting the refAngle's are added to ODE, which can be accessed via `SetParam` / `GetParam` in the physics Joint interface. Tests are added for these new API's to the `joint_spawn` test.

The `VariableGearboxPlugin` is a `ModelPlugin` that takes a `gearbox_joint_name` parameter and multiple `x_y_dydx` parameters. The `x_y_dydx` parameters specify points and slopes on the input-output curve. The snippet below is copied from `variable_gearbox_plugin.world`. Documentation of the spline math is provided in the code.

* x: angle of input joint
* y: angle of output joint
* dy/dx: instantaneous gear ratio of change in output / change in input.

~~~
<plugin name="variable_gearbox" filename="libVariableGearboxPlugin.so">
  <gearbox_joint_name>demo_joint_types::gearbox_demo</gearbox_joint_name>
  <x_y_dydx>1.2  -1.2  -1.0</x_y_dydx>
  <x_y_dydx>1.8  -7.5 -20.0</x_y_dydx>
</plugin>
~~~

The example world uses the `demo_joint_types` model, which has a pendulum connected via a gearbox to a flywheel. This plugin shifts the gear ratio from a low speed of the flywheel to a high speed as the pendulum swings.

values.description:
In PR [2058](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2058/added-camera-intrinsics-fx-fy-cx-cy-s) I am assuming the end users are aware that the OpenGL coordinate system is X\+ → left to right and Y\+ → bottom to top while OpenCV has the same X\+ but an inverted Y\+ \(top to bottom\).

Given that most of the end users will likely rely on OpenCV to calibrate the camera / projector, this implementation detail of OpenGL should probably be hidden from them.

As such, I added in this PR the necessary conversion of the y principal point \(the other intrinsic parameters do not require modification\).

I previously was doing this conversion within the calibration system that I developed on top of OpenCV calib3d module, but since most computer vision systems \(and literature / papers\) have a Y\+ → Top to bottom, it is probably better to perform it within Gazebo.

‌

I also added minor naming / coding style improvements.

‌

For future reference, I discussed the modeling of camera intrinsics in opengl in this paper:

“Modeling of video projectors in OpenGL for implementing a spatial augmented reality teaching system for assembly operations”

[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/332083524\_Modeling\_of\_video\_projectors\_in\_OpenGL\_for\_implementing\_a\_spatial\_augmented\_reality\_teaching\_system\_for\_assembly\_operations](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/332083524_Modeling_of_video_projectors_in_OpenGL_for_implementing_a_spatial_augmented_reality_teaching_system_for_assembly_operations)
values.title: Camera intrinsics - conversion of y principal point from OpenCV to OpenGL

In PR 2058 I am assuming the end users are aware that the OpenGL coordinate system is X+ → left to right and Y+ → bottom to top while OpenCV has the same X+ but an inverted Y+ (top to bottom).

Given that most of the end users will likely rely on OpenCV to calibrate the camera / projector, this implementation detail of OpenGL should probably be hidden from them.

As such, I added in this PR the necessary conversion of the y principal point (the other intrinsic parameters do not require modification).

I previously was doing this conversion within the calibration system that I developed on top of OpenCV calib3d module, but since most computer vision systems (and literature / papers) have a Y+ → Top to bottom, it is probably better to perform it within Gazebo.

‌

I also added minor naming / coding style improvements.

‌

For future reference, I discussed the modeling of camera intrinsics in opengl in this paper:

“Modeling of video projectors in OpenGL for implementing a spatial augmented reality teaching system for assembly operations”

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/332083524_Modeling_of_video_projectors_in_OpenGL_for_implementing_a_spatial_augmented_reality_teaching_system_for_assembly_operations

values.description:
fixes issue #2600  

# Issue

the `Boost_LIBRARIES` CMake variable contains `-lpthread` in addition to the absolute paths to the required boost libraries. The string processing in CMakeLists.txt adds an additional `-l` in front of it, resulting in `-l-lpthread` being added to the LIBS line.   

# Solution

Following the rpms patch, this PR works around the issue by checking each string to see if `-l` is already pre-pended to the string.
values.title: fix #2600 - remove prepending of additional -l with Boost_PKGCONFIG_LIBS

# Solution

Following the rpms patch, this PR works around the issue by checking each string to see if `-l` is already pre-pended to the string.

values.description:
Since the release of dart 6.7, which included a [refactor of the ConstraintSolver](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/pull/1099), our jenkins builds have shown two test failures of `INTEGRATION_kinematic_loop` for the dart test variant and compiler warnings complaining about use of deprecated syntax in DARTPhysics.cc.

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-default-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/385/testReport/
* https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-default-xenial-amd64-gpu-none/385/warnings22Result/

I reported this in #2605 and my struggles with using their new API, and @jlee02 promptly identified an issue and submitted https://github.com/dartsim/dart/pull/1260 to fix it. I've left the original code in place for dart 6.6 and earlier, and added two new ifdef blocks for dart 6.7 and the unreleased dart 6.8, which represents the contents of dart PR 1260.

I suppose we could skip the 6.8 ifdef, since the 6.7 one should still work, but I think the 6.8 version is a bit cleaner.

This should fix the test failures and compiler warnings. Thanks to @jlee02 for the prompt fixes and helpful suggestions!
values.title: Fix #2605: kinematic loops for DART 6.7 and later

Boost 1.69.0 removes the signals component, which gazebo was requesting via find_package. A fix was merged to gazebo9 in pull request #3050, but gazebo7 was not fixed. Since boost 1.69.0 was recently merged into homebrew-core, I was reminded of this because the gazebo7 bottle build failed:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder/label=osx_highsierra&build=219)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder/label=osx_highsierra/219/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder/label=osx_highsierra/219/

I grafted the same commits from pull request #3050 into this branch and applied two of them as patches to the gazebo7 formula, which fixed the bottle build:

* https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/649/commits/109044e7db18d60c6f32f4648521b8db0d1937ce
* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder&build=220)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder/220/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder/220/

values.description:
This is an issue reported from [https://github.com/ms-iot/ROSOnWindows/issues/48](https://github.com/ms-iot/ROSOnWindows/issues/48)

In our environment, `ign-cmake` is installed, and its `FindOgre.cmake` is first found and returns the OGRE path variables back to `gazebo-config.cmake`.  In this case, there are some difference found compared to `OgreConfig.cmake`:

1. `COMPONENTS Terrain Paging` is required for `FindOgre.cmake` to generate `Terrain` and `Paging` related path information.
2. `FindOgre.cmake` returns OGRE component path variables in different naming convention. For example, `OgreConfig.cmake` returns `OGRE_xxx_INCLUDE_DIRS`, but `FindOgre.cmake` returns `OGRE-xxx_INCLUDE_DIRS`.

‌

This change is proposing a change to accommodate both `FindOgre.cmake` and `OgreConfig.cmake` in `gazebo-config.cmake`.
values.title: [Gazebo9][Windows] Fixing OGRE Terrain &Paging INCLUDE_DIRS not folded into GAZEBO_INCLUDE_DIRS

values.description:
The LinkPlot3dPlugin can trace the paths of links in a simulation and is used with a `double_pendulum_with_base` model in [plot3d.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/676a14f7642c3516e6a779ac276e8898cd7d0f79/worlds/plot3d.world?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default). The double pendulum model is `<include>`d into the parent model as a sibling of the plugin element, which causes the double pendulum links to be added to the parent model with model namespacing using the `::` delimiter.

I tried following this pattern with the example world included in this pull request, which is a modified version of the [friction_cone.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/676a14f7642c3516e6a779ac276e8898cd7d0f79/test/worlds/friction_cone.world?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default), but it didn't work because this world has models [nested with explicit `<model>` tags](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/c2315ca10a801df4edcc174ccd9a5ccdbae4019d/worlds/friction_pyramid.world?fileviewer=file-view-default#friction_pyramid.world-19:20), and the LinkPlot3dPlugin is not able to find the specified links in this case. When I tried using `::` with the nested model name as a prefix, I saw console errors like the following:

~~~
[Err] [LinkPlot3DPlugin.cc:150] Couldn't find link [box_0::link_1] in model [boxes]
[Err] [LinkPlot3DPlugin.cc:150] Couldn't find link [box_1::link_1] in model [boxes]
[Err] [LinkPlot3DPlugin.cc:150] Couldn't find link [box_2::link_1] in model [boxes]
~~~

To find the links, the plugin needs to get a pointer to the nested model using the `Model::NestedModel` function. So if inside a `<plot>` element you specify a `<model>` tag with a model name alongside the `<link>` tag, it will now use that to search for a link inside a nested model.

Here's an animation of that test world with this branch:

* https://vimeo.com/327118010

and here's another animation if you change the `friction_model` tag to `cone_friction`:

* https://vimeo.com/327117996
values.title: LinkPlot3dPlugin: read optional <model> tag to find links in nested models

The LinkPlot3dPlugin can trace the paths of links in a simulation and is used with a double_pendulum_with_base model in plot3d.world. The double pendulum model is <include>d into the parent model as a sibling of the plugin element, which causes the double pendulum links to be added to the parent model with model namespacing using the :: delimiter.

I tried following this pattern with the example world included in this pull request, which is a modified version of the friction_cone.world, but it didn't work because this world has models nested with explicit <model> tags, and the LinkPlot3dPlugin is not able to find the specified links in this case. When I tried using :: with the nested model name as a prefix, I saw console errors like the following:

[Err] [LinkPlot3DPlugin.cc:150] Couldn't find link [box_0::link_1] in model [boxes]
[Err] [LinkPlot3DPlugin.cc:150] Couldn't find link [box_1::link_1] in model [boxes]
[Err] [LinkPlot3DPlugin.cc:150] Couldn't find link [box_2::link_1] in model [boxes]

To find the links, the plugin needs to get a pointer to the nested model using the Model::NestedModel function. So if inside a <plot> element you specify a <model> tag with a model name alongside the <link> tag, it will now use that to search for a link inside a nested model.

Here's an animation of that test world with this branch:

  • https://vimeo.com/327118010

and here's another animation if you change the friction_model tag to cone_friction:

  • https://vimeo.com/327117996

values.description:
This seems to fix a crash in ARIAC 2019 [https://bitbucket.org/osrf/ariac/issues/160/](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/ariac/issues/160/) .

The traceback for the crash goes deep inside `std::map::operator[]()` at [this line](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/676a14f7642c3516e6a779ac276e8898cd7d0f79/gazebo/transport/TopicManager.cc#lines-238) in `TopicManager::Subscribe()`. This map operation [isn’t thread safe](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/container#Thread_safety), and the [ROSLaserPlugin creates gazebo transport subscribers in a separate thread](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/ariac/src/18dd570b99e614ea5737ca38b2f8048a2c312c74/osrf_gear/src/ROSLaserPlugin.cc#lines-118:119). The `TopicManager` appears to have a member `subscriberMutex` for protecting the map `subscriberNodes`, but it is not locked in `TopicManager::Subscribe()`. This PR makes sure `subscriberMutex` is locked anywhere `subscriberNodes` is used. I tested by restarting ARIAC 20 times with and without this change. Without this change it crashed 3/20 times, and with this change it did not crash at all.
values.title: Lock subscriberMutex anywhere subscribedNodes is used

summary.html:
This seems to fix a crash in ARIAC 2019 https://bitbucket.org/osrf/ariac/issues/160/ .

The traceback for the crash goes deep inside std::map::operator[]() at this line in TopicManager::Subscribe(). This map operation isn’t thread safe, and the ROSLaserPlugin creates gazebo transport subscribers in a separate thread. The TopicManager appears to have a member subscriberMutex for protecting the map subscriberNodes, but it is not locked in TopicManager::Subscribe(). This PR makes sure subscriberMutex is locked anywhere subscriberNodes is used. I tested by restarting ARIAC 20 times with and without this change. Without this change it crashed 3/20 times, and with this change it did not crash at all.

values.description:
This PR implements a workaround that addresses issue #1858 and [this question](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/12553/road-visuals-not-shown-in-published-camera-image). My particular use case is to:

* Load a Gazebo world with `<road>` elements
* Spawn a car model with a front-facing camera to simulate in ROS
* Process the camera image output to simulate lane detection

I had the same problem as shown in the above referenced issue and question where the road textures did not appear in the camera image output.

I found the root cause of this issue. Before this PR, when the `World` class parses a world file with `<road>` elements, it sends Gazebo `Road` messages before any models are loaded and ready to receive them. This causes models with camera sensors to miss the road messages, which makes the roads invisible in the camera image output.

The workaround re-transmits the `Road` messages at the first physics update and whenever a new model is loaded. This way, everything that needs to know about the road segments won't miss the messages.

This workaround seems inelegant, but it definitely solved my problem and I think will solve the problem in the above referenced question. Perhaps someone more familiar with the Gazebo source can suggest a better way to fix this?
values.title: Workaround for road segments in world file not being visible in camera sensor output

Backport of pull request #2058. I also adapted the the changes from pull request #3076.

Added `camera_intrinsics.world` as an example world to demonstrate the camera intrinsics feature.

Note: In order to preserve ABI, two protected variables are added to the private data class `CameraPrivate.hh` instead of `Camera.hh`. I’ve added a note as a reminder when merging forward.

summary.html:
This is a follow-up to PR #3086, which fixed issue #2605 (kinematic loops in dart 6.7+). In that pull request, I added ifdef blocks for dart 6.7 and dart 6.8+, but it appears that the block for dart 6.8+ is broken. For now, we can just use the 6.7 API.

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo9-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/76/

@jlee02 do we need to use a new API from dart 6.8 to specify a secondary LCP solver? I hadn't gotten around to testing that yet.
